sn22.55:4.2: There the Buddha uttered this aphorism:
sn22.55:4.3: “‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.55:4.4: A mendicant who makes such a resolution can cut off the five lower fetters.”
sn22.55:4.5: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha:
sn22.55:4.7: can a mendicant who makes such a resolution cut off the five lower fetters?”
sn22.55:5.1: “Mendicant, take an uneducated ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in their teaching. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in their teaching.
sn22.55:5.2: They regard form as self, self as having form,
sn22.55:5.3: form in self, or self in form.
sn22.55:5.7: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness,
sn22.55:5.8: consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
sn22.55:6.1: They don’t truly understand form—which is impermanent—as impermanent. They don’t truly understand feeling … perception … choices … consciousness—which is impermanent—as impermanent.
sn22.55:7.1: They don’t truly understand form—which is suffering—as suffering. They don’t truly understand feeling …
sn22.55:8.1: They don’t truly understand form—which is not-self—as not-self. They don’t truly understand feeling … perception … choices … consciousness—which is not-self—as not-self.
sn22.55:9.1: They don’t truly understand form—which is conditioned—as conditioned. They don’t truly understand feeling … perception … choices … consciousness—which is conditioned—as conditioned.
sn22.55:9.5: They don’t truly understand that form will disappear.
sn22.55:9.6: They don’t truly understand that feeling …
sn22.55:10.1: But an educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in their teaching. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in their teaching. They don’t regard form as self …
sn22.55:11.1: They truly understand form—which is impermanent—as impermanent.
sn22.55:11.6: They truly understand form … feeling … perception … choices …
sn22.55:11.8: They truly understand form … feeling … perception … choices …
sn22.55:11.10: They truly understand form … feeling … perception … choices …
sn22.55:11.12: They truly understand that form will disappear.
sn22.55:12.1: It’s because of the disappearance of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that a mendicant who makes such a resolution—‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine’—
sn22.55:12.2: can cut off the five lower fetters.”
sn22.55:12.3: “Sir, a mendicant who makes such a resolution can cut off the five lower fetters.
sn22.55:13.1: But how are they to know and see in order to end the defilements in the present life?”
sn22.55:13.2: “Mendicant, an uneducated ordinary person worries about things that aren’t a worry.
sn22.55:13.3: For an uneducated ordinary person worries:
sn22.55:13.4: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.55:14.1: An educated noble disciple doesn’t worry about things that aren’t a worry.
sn22.55:14.2: For an educated noble disciple doesn’t worry:
sn22.55:14.3: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.55:14.4: As long as consciousness remains, it would remain involved with form, supported by form, founded on form. And with a sprinkle of relishing, it would grow, increase, and mature.
sn22.55:14.5: Or consciousness would remain involved with feeling …
sn22.55:14.6: Or consciousness would remain involved with perception …
sn22.55:14.7: Or consciousness would remain involved with choices, supported by choices, grounded on choices. And with a sprinkle of relishing, it would grow, increase, and mature.
sn22.55:15.2: ‘Apart from form, feeling, perception, and choices, I will describe the coming and going of consciousness, its passing away and reappearing, its growth, increase, and maturity.’ That is not possible.
sn22.55:16.1: If a mendicant has given up greed for the form element,
sn22.55:16.2: the support is cut off, and there is no foundation for consciousness.
sn22.55:16.3: If a mendicant has given up greed for the feeling element …
sn22.55:16.7: the support is cut off, and there is no foundation for consciousness.
sn22.55:16.8: Since that consciousness has no foundation, it doesn’t increase; with no power to regenerate, it is freed.
sn22.55:16.12: Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
sn22.55:16.14: there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn22.55:16.15: The ending of the defilements is for one who knows and sees this.”
